text: So, here we're using going to to express the future tense in French.
However, this is not the only way we're limited to expressing the future tense in French.
And the way we're going to express it is going to be extremely easy.
Before we do it, though, I just need to remind you of something.
What is you formal have in French?
Vous avez
And we have?
Nous avons
I have
J'ai
He has
Il a
She has
Elle a
Finally, they have
Ils ont
Now, we've used have for things such as the past tense in French.
But now, we're going to use it in order to make another future tense.
And it's going to be pretty easy to do so.
What is to eat in French?
Manger
And what is I have?
J'ai
Now, which part of the word
J'ai
Actually means have?
Et
So, you have the word for I, which is
Je
And the word for have, which is
Et
Again, what was he has?
Il a
And which is the actual word that means has?
A
And again, what was to eat?
Manger
How would you say, literally, he to eat in French?
Il mange
What we're going to do now
Is on the end of that sentence, which won't seem to make much sense to you at the moment
Is we're going to add the word for has, for he
So again, what was he has?
Il a
And so, the word for has is
A
I want you to put that word onto the end of to eat
What will that give you?
So we've got to eat, which is
Manger
And you're going to put an A right on the end
What will you end up with, do you think?
Now, it's worth checking the spelling for a moment of what you will end up with
You'll end up with
M
A
N
G
E
R
A
And because you've got that R A at the end
You will hear the sound very clearly of a
Ra
So again, how would you say that with a
With to eat, with an A added on the end, how will it be pronounced?
Manger
So at the moment, again, you're not sure what this actually means
But I want you to go a step further with me
Now put the word for he in front of all that
So literally, you will have a sentence that says
He to eat has
How would you say that?
He mangera
Now, in French, that actually means he will eat
It seems very unusual to us that they would say it in that way, to say he to eat has actually
means he will eat, but that's how it's done in French.
Of course, you don't have to say it. If you want, you can say he's going to eat.
How would you say that? He's going to eat.
Il va manger.
Il va manger.
But quite often, instead, you will say he will eat, which is he to eat has. Again, how will you say that?
Il mangera.
How do you think you'd say she will eat?
Elle mangera.
Now, let's go back to that word for I have in French. I have. How do you say it again?
J'ai.
And which part of that is the have?
Eh.
So, again, if you want to say, for instance, I will eat, you again will say I to eat,
and then you'll use the word for have, for I, and put it on the end,
which will give you a sort of a ray sound at the end, almost.
So, again, how would you say I to eat have, which means literally I will eat?
How would you say that?
Je mangerai.
So, let's do it one more time.
He will eat.
Il mangera.
She will eat.
Elle mangera.
Both with the appropriate word for have or has on the end.
But the word for have for I is different.
So, again, what will be I will eat?
Je mangerai.
Let's look at you have formal.
What is you have?
Vous avez.
Now, let's try adding that on the end of to have.
What would you have in that instance?
You'd get mangera.
You'd get mangera.
Now, that's a bit long for French.
It's a bit too long.
So, what's going to happen is we're going to get rid of the AV of the ave.
So, instead of mangera.
You're going to lose that ave.
And what are you going to have instead?
If you get rid of the AV, what are you going to have?
You're going to have...
mangerai.
So, how would you say you will eat?
Vous mangerai.
